Previous: Session 14 — Sound Engineering Next: Session 16 — Community Helpers

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 16 of 17

Students design solutions to help their community, applying engineering skills to serve others.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Identify needs in their community

  • Design a solution to help someone

  • Build or plan a service project

  • Connect engineering to Catholic social teaching

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📦 Building materials (cardboard, craft sticks, tape)

  • 🎨 Art supplies

  • 📋 "Community Needs" brainstorm sheet

  • 📓 Engineering journals

  • 📸 Pictures of community helpers

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: St. Vincent de Paul — He organized help for the poor, creating systems to serve those in need.

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "Serve one another humbly in love." — Galatians 5:13

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, you call us to love our neighbors. Help us see what our community needs. Give us creative ideas to help others. Bless the work of our hands. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Community Helpers — "Who helps in our community?"
  2. Police, firefighters, nurses, teachers
  3. Mail carriers, trash collectors, store workers
  4. Parents, volunteers, neighbors
  5. Everyone Can Help — "YOU can be a community helper too!"
  6. Engineering for Good — "We can use our design skills to help people!"
  7. Today's Mission — "Design something that helps our community!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Service Design Project (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Identify Needs (4 minutes)

  • Brainstorm community needs:
  • Elderly neighbors need help with tasks
  • Homeless need warm clothes
  • Animals need shelter
  • Environment needs care (litter cleanup)

  • Lonely people need friendship

  • Pick one need to address

Part 2: Design & Build (13 minutes)

Option A: Bird Feeder for Creation Care

  • Simple design from recyclables

  • Helps birds, beautifies community

  • Build and take home

Option B: Kindness Kit Design

  • Design a "kit" for someone in need

  • What would go inside?

  • Draw and label items

  • Plan to assemble real ones

Option C: Thank You Signs

  • Create signs for community helpers

  • "Thank you, mail carrier!"

  • Display in windows or deliver

Option D: Free Design

  • Student identifies need and solution

  • Build prototype or detailed plan

  • Present to class

Part 3: Share Plans (2 minutes)

  • Groups share what they designed

  • "How will this help?"

docs.title: Engineering Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw your design
  2. Write: "This helps... by..."
  3. Write: "One thing I can do this week to help someone is..."

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Service Summary — "How can engineers help communities?"
  2. Challenge — "This week, be a community helper!"
  3. Closing Prayer — "God, help us be your hands and feet. Show us how to serve others every day. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Identified community need

  • Designed thoughtful solution

  • Connected design to service

  • Committed to action

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Join group with clear role

  • Focus on one simple project

  • Teacher-guided brainstorming

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Create detailed implementation plan

  • Design multiple solutions

  • Lead group discussion

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Do a family service project! Ideas: Make bird feeders, pick up litter, bake treats for neighbors, donate toys, write thank you notes to community helpers. Talk about how it feels to help.

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Follow through on any service projects planned

  • Connect to school/parish service initiatives

  • Consider class "Day of Service"

  • Embodies Catholic Social Teaching: dignity of workers, care for community

Previous: Session 15 — Robot Challenge Next: Session 17 — Year Exhibition

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 17 of 17

Students celebrate their year of C-STREAM learning, sharing portfolios and demonstrating growth in engineering, coding, and faith integration.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Reflect on their year of learning

  • Share accomplishments with others

  • Demonstrate growth in C-STREAM skills

  • Celebrate faith and reason together

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📓 Engineering journals (from all year)

  • 📸 Photos from C-STREAM sessions

  • 🏆 Certificates (optional)

  • 🎨 Display materials

  • 📋 "I Learned..." reflection sheet

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: All the Saints We Met This Year — St. Joseph, St. Francis, St. Cecilia, Blessed Carlo Acutis, and more! They showed us that faith and learning go together.

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "I thank my God every time I remember you." — Philippians 1:3

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, thank you for an amazing year of discovery! Thank you for letting us learn about your wonderful world. Thank you for our teachers and friends. Bless us as we continue to grow. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Celebration! — "We've completed a whole year of C-STREAM!"
  2. Memory Lane — Show photos from throughout the year
  3. Count Our Learning:
  4. 17 sessions of exploring!
  5. Bridges, robots, coding, instruments, and more!
  6. Saints Remembered — Quick mention of saints we met
  7. Today's Celebration — "Share what you've learned!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Exhibition (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Portfolio Review (5 minutes)

  • Students look through their engineering journals

  • Mark favorite pages with sticky notes

  • Identify: "My best work" and "My biggest growth"

Part 2: Partner Sharing (6 minutes)

  • Share with a partner:
  • One project you're proud of
  • Something that was hard but you figured out

  • Your favorite saint we learned about

  • Partners encourage each other

Part 3: Class Gallery (5 minutes)

  • Display journals and projects

  • Gallery walk to see everyone's work

  • Positive comments only!

Part 4: Awards & Recognition (3 minutes)

  • Optional certificates:
  • "Wonder Champion"
  • "Master Builder"
  • "Code Creator"
  • "Service Star"

  • "Faith & Reason Explorer"

  • Recognize every student's growth

docs.title: Reflection & Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. In journal, write/draw:
  2. My favorite C-STREAM memory
  3. Something I learned about God's world
  4. What I want to learn next year

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Gratitude Round — Each student: "I'm thankful for..."
  2. Future Engineers — "You're ready for more adventures!"
  3. Final Blessing & Prayer:

Dear God, Thank you for this year of wonder. Thank you for curious minds and creative hands. Thank you for showing us that faith and science are friends. Bless these young engineers as they grow. Help them always use their gifts for good. In Jesus' name, Amen.

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
End-of-Year Reflection:

  • Can identify learning growth

  • Expresses pride in accomplishments

  • Connects C-STREAM to faith

  • Shows enthusiasm for future learning

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Pre-select journal highlights

  • Partner with supportive peer

  • Focus on verbal sharing

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Present to the class

  • Create "tips" for next year's students

  • Write reflection letter

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text:
Summer Challenge: Keep being a C-STREAM explorer all summer!

  • Build with whatever you find

  • Ask "I wonder..." questions

  • Look for God's patterns in nature

  • Use technology for good

  • Help others with your skills

  • Never stop wondering!

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Prepare certificates in advance

  • Invite parents/families if possible

  • Take lots of photos

  • Send journals home as keepsakes

  • Celebrate each child's unique growth

docs.title: 🎊 Congratulations, C-STREAM Engineers! 🎊
docs.text:
You've completed Grades 1-2 Year A C-STREAM!

This year you:

  • ✅ Built bridges and towers

  • ✅ Programmed Dash Robots

  • ✅ Created code with ScratchJr

  • ✅ Explored God's patterns

  • ✅ Engineered instruments

  • ✅ Served your community

  • ✅ Connected faith and reason

You are engineers, scientists, and children of God!

Keep building. Keep wondering. Keep praising God.

Previous: Session 16 — Community Helpers

End of Grades 1-2 Year A Bi-Weekly C-STREAM Curriculum

docs.title: 🌟 Grades 1-2 Year B Bi-Weekly C-STREAM
docs.text:
17 Sessions | 30 Minutes Each | Every Other Week

This folder contains the condensed Grades 1-2 Year B C-STREAM curriculum for schools with bi-weekly STREAM classes. Year B features different projects, saints, and contexts than Year A while building the same foundational skills.

docs.title: 📋 Session Overview
docs.text: Session Title Theme Key Activity Session 01 Design Detectives Introduction Everyday design Session 02 Tower Power Engineering Tower challenges Session 03 Meet Sphero Technology Sphero basics Session 04 Animal Adaptations Science Animal design Session 05 Garden Engineers Life Science Garden design Session 06 Gratitude Gifts Thanksgiving Gift creation Session 07 Star Makers Advent Star engineering Session 08 Digital Art Technology Digital creation Session 09 Faith Scientists Catholic Schools Women in STEM Session 10 Magnets & Motion Science Magnetism Session 11 Lenten Love Service Service project Session 12 Butterfly Wonder Life Cycles Metamorphosis Session 13 Easter Joy Resurrection New life celebration Session 14 Sphero Challenge Technology Robot missions Session 15 Simple Machines Engineering Levers and pulleys Session 16 Earth Care Environment Creation care Session 17 Year Celebration Exhibition Portfolio showcase

docs.title: 🎯 Year B Learning Goals
docs.text:
By the end of the year, Grades 1-2 students will:

  • ✅ Apply design thinking to new challenges

  • ✅ Program Sphero robots for various tasks

  • ✅ Create digital art using tablets

  • ✅ Explore animal adaptations and life cycles

  • ✅ Connect faith to environmental stewardship

  • ✅ Serve others through engineering projects

docs.title: From CSCOE Library
docs.text:
• Sphero Robots & Tablets

  • KEVA Planks

  • Simple Machines Kit

  • Magnet exploration kit

  • Butterfly/Life cycle materials

docs.title: Technology
docs.text:
• Sphero Edu app

  • Drawing/art apps on tablets

docs.title: Classroom Supplies
docs.text:
• Craft materials for building

  • Garden supplies

  • Construction paper

docs.title: 🔄 Year A / Year B Rotation
docs.text:
Year B focuses on:

  • 🏰 Tower building and habitats

  • 🤖 Sphero robot programming

  • 🦋 Butterflies and animal adaptations

  • 🎨 Digital art creation

  • 🌍 Environmental stewardship

Year A (alternate year) focuses on:

  • 🌉 Bridge building

  • 🤖 Dash Robot programming

  • 🌱 Plant life cycles

  • 🎵 Sound and instruments

  • 👥 Community helpers

Grades 1-2 Year B Bi-Weekly — New challenges, same wonder!

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 1 of 17

Students become Design Detectives, discovering that everything around us was designed by someone to solve a problem or meet a need.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Recognize that objects are designed with purpose

  • Identify problems that designs solve

  • Begin thinking like designers

  • Connect human creativity to God-given gifts

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📦 Collection of everyday objects (scissors, cup, shoe, pencil, backpack)

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 🔍 Magnifying glasses

  • 🖍️ Crayons/pencils

  • 📋 "Design Detective" badges (paper)

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: Blessed Fra Angelico — A Dominican friar who used his artistic talents to design beautiful paintings for God's glory.

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "Every good and perfect gift is from above." — James 1:17

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, thank you for giving people creative minds to design things that help us. Help us be good designers who think about others. Bless our discovering today. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (6 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Detective Mission — "Today we become DESIGN DETECTIVES!"
  2. Everything is Designed — "Look around—someone DESIGNED everything you see!"
  3. Design Questions:
  4. WHO designed this?
  5. WHY did they make it?
  6. What PROBLEM does it solve?
  7. God's Gift — "God gave people creativity to design helpful things"
  8. Badge Distribution — Hand out Design Detective badges!

docs.title: Main Activity: Design Investigation (18 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Object Investigation (8 minutes)

  • Small groups receive everyday objects

  • Detective questions for each:

  • What is it?
  • What is it made of?
  • What problem does it solve?

  • How could it be better?

  • Record observations

Part 2: Class Share (4 minutes)

  • Each group presents one object

  • "This [object] was designed to..."

  • Class discusses: "What would life be without it?"

Part 3: Your Turn! (6 minutes)

  • Think of a problem you have

  • Draw a design that could solve it

  • Examples: Homework holder, snack carrier, toy organizer

  • Share with a partner

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw one object you investigated
  2. Write: "It was designed to..."
  3. Draw YOUR design idea

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Detective Discovery — "What surprised you about design?"
  2. Year Ahead — "We'll design and build all year!"
  3. Closing Prayer — "Thank you, God, for creative minds. Help us design things that help others. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Identified purpose of designed objects

  • Asked thoughtful questions

  • Created original design idea

  • Recorded in journal

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Focus on 2-3 familiar objects

  • Partner investigation

  • Draw-only journal entry

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Investigate more complex objects

  • Write about design features

  • Create detailed design plans

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Be Design Detectives at home! Pick 5 objects and figure out what problems they solve. What objects could be designed better? Draw your improvement ideas!

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Save Design Detective badges for year-long use

  • Start collecting interesting objects for future sessions

  • Journals will be used throughout the year

  • Connect to inventions and inventors

Next Session: Session 02 — Tower Power

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 2 of 17

Students explore what makes structures stable, designing and building towers that are tall AND strong.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Understand that wide bases provide stability

  • Build towers using various materials

  • Test structures for height and strength

  • Practice iteration (trying again to improve)

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📦 KEVA Planks (from CSCOE library)

  • 📦 Cups (paper or plastic)

  • 📦 Index cards

  • 📏 Measuring stick or tape measure

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 📸 Pictures of famous towers

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: St. Barbara — Patron saint of architects and builders. She's remembered for her faith that was strong like a tower!

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "The name of the Lord is a fortified tower; the righteous run to it and are safe." — Proverbs 18:10

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, you are our strong tower! Help us build towers today that are strong and stable. When we face challenges, remind us that you are our strength. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Famous Towers — Show pictures:
  2. Eiffel Tower
  3. Leaning Tower of Pisa
  4. Church bell towers
  5. What Makes Towers Strong?
  6. Wide base
  7. Balanced weight
  8. Strong materials
  9. Today's Challenge — "Build the TALLEST tower that can stand for 10 seconds!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Tower Engineering (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Quick Challenge - Cup Towers (6 minutes)

  • Partners receive 10 cups

  • Challenge: Build as tall as possible

  • Test: Does it stand for 10 seconds?

  • Observe: What patterns make towers stable?

Part 2: KEVA Plank Towers (10 minutes)

  • Switch to KEVA Planks

  • Challenge: Build taller than a ruler (12 inches)!

  • Design considerations:

  • Start with wide base
  • Build symmetrically

  • Test as you build

  • Measure final heights

Part 3: Improvement Round (3 minutes)

  • "What would make your tower stronger?"

  • One more try to improve!

  • Compare: Better? What changed?

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw your tallest tower
  2. Label: Base, middle, top
  3. Write: "My tower was ___ inches tall"
  4. Write: "Strong towers need..."

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Tower Secrets — "What makes towers stable?"
  2. Faith Connection — "God is our strong tower!"
  3. Closing Prayer — "Thank you, God, for being our strong tower. Help us build strong structures and strong faith. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Built towers using multiple materials

  • Identified features of stable structures

  • Measured and compared heights

  • Improved designs through iteration

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Focus on cup stacking only

  • Lower height goal (6 inches)

  • Build alongside teacher

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Must support a book on top

  • Try multiple tower designs

  • Record data systematically

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Build towers at home with blocks, cups, cards, or food cans. Have a family tower competition! What made the winning tower special? Visit or look up pictures of the Eiffel Tower.

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Reserve KEVA Planks from CSCOE 2 weeks ahead

  • Save tower measurement data for comparison

  • Take photos of successful designs

  • Connect to architecture and construction careers

Previous: Session 01 — Design Detectives Next: Session 03 — Meet Sphero

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 3 of 17

Students are introduced to Sphero robots, learning to control the rolling robot and understanding basic programming concepts.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Understand that Sphero follows programmed instructions

  • Learn basic Sphero controls (drive, speed, direction)

  • Navigate Sphero through simple paths

  • Connect technology to responsible use

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📦 Sphero robots (from CSCOE library)

  • 📱 Tablets with Sphero Edu app

  • 🚧 Tape for paths on floor

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 📋 Sphero control reference cards

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: Blessed Carlo Acutis — A teenager who loved technology and used it to share faith. He created websites about miracles!

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "Whatever you do, work at it with all your heart, as working for the Lord." — Colossians 3:23

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, thank you for technology and the creative people who make it. Help us use technology wisely, like Blessed Carlo Acutis did. Bless our learning today. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Meet Sphero! — Show the robot
  2. "This is Sphero—a robot ball!"
  3. "WE tell it what to do!"
  4. Robot Review:
  5. Robots follow instructions
  6. They don't think—they obey our commands
  7. Blessed Carlo — Used computers to serve God
  8. Today's Goal — "Learn to control Sphero!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Sphero Introduction (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: First Connection (4 minutes)

  • Small groups receive Sphero and tablet

  • Open Sphero Edu app

  • Connect to Sphero (teacher helps)

  • Explore: Touch the screen—what happens?

Part 2: Basic Driving (7 minutes)

  • Use "Drive" mode

  • Practice:

  • Go forward
  • Go backward
  • Turn left/right

  • Change speed (slow is better for control!)

  • Challenge: Drive in a straight line

Part 3: Path Challenge (6 minutes)

  • Simple taped path on floor

  • Challenge: Drive Sphero along the path

  • Stay on the line!

  • Partners take turns

Part 4: Color Fun (2 minutes)

  • Change Sphero's colors

  • Make it flash!

  • "Robots can do fun things too!"

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw Sphero
  2. Write: "To control Sphero, I..."
  3. Draw the path you drove
  4. Rate: Easy 😊 Medium 😐 Hard 😰

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. What We Learned — "Who's in charge—us or Sphero?"
  2. Responsible Tech — "How do we use technology well?"
  3. Closing Prayer — "Thank you, God, for robots and technology. Help us use them to do good things. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Successfully connected to Sphero

  • Demonstrated basic driving control

  • Completed path challenge

  • Understood human control over robots

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Extra time with controls

  • Simpler path (straight line)

  • Partner driving

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Complex path with turns

  • Speed challenge (slow and accurate)

  • Explore additional app features

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Talk about robots at home! Where do we see robots? (Vacuums, factories, space) Play "robot"—give family members exact instructions to follow. How important is being specific?

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Reserve Sphero from CSCOE 2 weeks ahead

  • Charge robots fully before session

  • Sphero Edu app is free

  • Have backup activities if tech issues arise

Previous: Session 02 — Tower Power Next: Session 04 — Animal Adaptations

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 4 of 17

Students explore how God designed animals with special features (adaptations) that help them survive in their environments.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Understand that adaptations help animals survive

  • Identify examples of animal adaptations

  • Design an animal for a specific environment

  • Connect animal design to God's wisdom

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📸 Pictures of animals with adaptations

  • 🎨 Drawing supplies

  • 📦 Craft materials for "design an animal" (optional)

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 📋 Habitat cards (desert, arctic, ocean, forest)

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: St. Francis of Assisi — He loved all animals and called them his "brothers and sisters," seeing God's care in every creature.

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "Ask the animals, and they will teach you." — Job 12:7

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, you made every animal with special gifts to help it survive. Thank you for your wisdom in creation. Help us learn from the animals today. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (6 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Animal Wonder — "Why do polar bears have white fur?"
  2. Adaptations — "God designed animals with special features!"
  3. Examples:
  4. 🦅 Eagle: Sharp eyes to see food
  5. 🐪 Camel: Humps to store water
  6. 🐻‍❄️ Polar bear: White fur to hide in snow
  7. 🐟 Fish: Gills to breathe underwater
  8. St. Francis — "He knew animals teach us about God!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Adaptation Exploration (18 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Adaptation Gallery (5 minutes)

  • Show animal pictures with adaptations

  • For each animal:

  • What special feature do you see?
  • How does it help the animal?

  • Where does this animal live?

  • Students make observations

Part 2: Match the Adaptation (4 minutes)

  • Activity: Match animals to their habitats

  • Why does each animal fit its home?

  • Discuss: "What would happen if a polar bear lived in the desert?"

Part 3: Design Your Animal (9 minutes)

  • Choose a habitat (desert, arctic, ocean, forest)

  • Design an animal that could live there

  • What adaptations does it need?

  • Desert: Big ears (cooling), stores water
  • Arctic: Thick fur, white color
  • Ocean: Fins, gills, streamlined

  • Forest: Camouflage, claws for climbing

  • Draw and label your animal's features

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw your designed animal
  2. Label its special adaptations
  3. Write: "My animal lives in ___ because..."

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Share Designs — Quick show of created animals
  2. God's Wisdom — "God knew exactly what each animal needed!"
  3. Closing Prayer — "Thank you, God, for your amazing animal designs. Help us take care of all your creatures. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Identified animal adaptations

  • Connected adaptations to survival

  • Designed animal with appropriate features

  • Related design to habitat

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Focus on 2-3 clear examples

  • Choose from adaptation options

  • Partner work for design

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Design animal for unusual habitat

  • Multiple adaptations with explanations

  • Research real animals with unique features

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Watch an animal documentary together! Look for adaptations. Visit a zoo and notice what makes each animal special. Design a creature together for a made-up habitat!

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Great connection to science curriculum

  • Consider showing video clips of animals

  • This prepares for habitat building later

  • Connect to environmental stewardship

Previous: Session 03 — Meet Sphero Next: Session 05 — Garden Engineers

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 5 of 17

Students design and begin a garden project, learning about plants and practicing creation care as environmental stewards.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Understand what plants need to grow

  • Design a garden layout

  • Plant seeds and care for them

  • Connect gardening to caring for God's creation

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📦 Seeds (fast-growing: beans, sunflowers, or herbs)

  • 🪴 Small pots or cups

  • 🌱 Potting soil

  • 💧 Spray bottles for watering

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 📋 "What Plants Need" chart

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: St. Fiacre — Patron saint of gardeners! He grew beautiful gardens and used his harvest to help the poor.

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "The Lord God took the man and put him in the Garden of Eden to work it and take care of it." — Genesis 2:15

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, you created the first garden in Eden and asked us to take care of it. Help us be good gardeners who love and protect your creation. Bless these seeds we plant today. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Garden Wonder — "Have you ever grown a plant?"
  2. Plants Need:
  3. ☀️ Light (sun)
  4. 💧 Water
  5. 🪴 Soil (nutrients)
  6. 💨 Air
  7. St. Fiacre — Grew gardens to help others!
  8. Today's Project — "We're becoming garden engineers!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Garden Design & Planting (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Design Our Garden (5 minutes)

  • What will we grow?

  • Draw a garden plan:

  • Where will pots go?
  • What plants?

  • Who will care for them?

  • Discuss class garden location (sunny window)

Part 2: Plant Seeds (10 minutes)

  • Each student gets a pot/cup

  • Planting steps:

  • Fill with soil (almost full)
  • Make small hole with finger
  • Place seed in hole
  • Cover gently with soil

  • Water lightly

  • Label pot with name and date

Part 3: Care Plan (4 minutes)

  • How will we care for our plants?

  • Create watering schedule

  • What will we look for?

  • Predict: When will we see sprouts?

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw your planted seed/pot
  2. Write: "Plants need..."
  3. Predict: "In ___ days, my plant will..."
  4. Draw what you think it will look like grown

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Garden Responsibility — "How will we care for our garden?"
  2. Creation Care — "Taking care of plants is taking care of God's world!"
  3. Closing Prayer — "God, bless these seeds and help them grow. Teach us to care for all of your creation. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Identified plant needs

  • Followed planting steps

  • Created care plan

  • Connected gardening to creation care

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Partner planting

  • Pre-measured soil amounts

  • Visual step-by-step cards

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Plant multiple seed types

  • Research plant needs in depth

  • Design detailed garden plan

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Plant something at home! Beans grow quickly. Watch and record what happens each day. Talk about how taking care of plants is taking care of God's creation.

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Plants will need daily watering—assign student helpers

  • Keep near sunny window

  • Fast-growing options: beans (7-10 days), grass seed (3-5 days)

  • Consider sending plants home at year end

Previous: Session 04 — Animal Adaptations Next: Session 06 — Gratitude Gifts

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 6 of 17

Students express thankfulness by designing and creating handmade gifts for people they appreciate.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Express gratitude for people in their lives

  • Design a meaningful gift for someone

  • Create a handmade item with intention

  • Connect giving to Catholic social teaching

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 🎨 Craft supplies (paper, markers, ribbons)

  • 📦 Card-making materials

  • 🖼️ Small frames or photo holders (optional)

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • ❤️ Heart shapes

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: St. Thérèse of Lisieux — She believed in doing small things with great love. Even little gifts can show big love!

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "Give thanks in all circumstances." — 1 Thessalonians 5:18

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, we have so much to thank you for! Help us remember all the people who help us. May our gifts today show our love and gratitude. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Gratitude Circle — Each person shares one thing they're thankful for
  2. People Who Help Us:
  3. Family
  4. Teachers
  5. Friends
  6. Church community
  7. Neighbors
  8. St. Thérèse — "Little things done with love matter most!"
  9. Today's Project — "Design a gift to show gratitude!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Gift Design & Creation (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Design Thinking (4 minutes)

  • Who will receive your gift?

  • What do they like?

  • What would make them smile?

  • Sketch your gift idea

Part 2: Create Your Gift (13 minutes)

Option A: Thank You Card

  • Decorated card with personal message

  • Include: Why you're thankful for them

  • Add drawings, stickers, hearts

Option B: Bookmark

  • Decorated bookmark

  • "Thank you for..." message

  • For teachers, librarians, readers

Option C: Picture Frame/Holder

  • Decorate a small frame

  • Add: "I'm thankful for you!"

  • Gift to family member

Option D: Custom Design

  • Student's own gift idea

  • Must express gratitude

  • Created with care

Part 3: Reflection (2 minutes)

  • How does it feel to make something for someone else?

  • How do you think they'll feel?

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw the gift you created
  2. Write: "I made this for ___ because..."
  3. Write: "Giving makes me feel..."

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Gift Preview — Show what you made (keep recipients secret!)
  2. Giving Joy — "It's better to give than receive!"
  3. Closing Prayer — "Thank you, God, for everyone who loves us. Help our gifts bring joy. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Identified someone to thank

  • Designed with recipient in mind

  • Created gift with care

  • Expressed gratitude through work

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Choose from 2 options

  • Template for card design

  • Work alongside teacher

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Make gifts for multiple people

  • Write longer messages

  • Create original gift design

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Have a family gratitude night! Each person makes a gift for another family member. Share what you're thankful for about each person. Start a "Thankful Jar" for November.

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Time gift completion for family events

  • Consider class gift for school staff

  • Display gratitude art on bulletin board

  • Connect to school Thanksgiving activities

Previous: Session 05 — Garden Engineers Next: Session 07 — Star Makers

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 7 of 17

Students explore stars and light during Advent, engineering their own star creations that shine with the message of Jesus as Light.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Explore properties of stars and light

  • Engineer a 3D star structure

  • Connect the Star of Bethlehem to Advent

  • Understand Jesus as "Light of the World"

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📦 Craft sticks (for star frames)

  • ✨ Glitter, foil, metallic paper

  • 🔦 Flashlights

  • 📦 Pipe cleaners

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 📸 Pictures of stars, night sky, Star of Bethlehem

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: The Magi (Wise Men) — They followed a star to find Jesus! Stars can lead us to God.

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "We saw his star when it rose and have come to worship him." — Matthew 2:2

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear Jesus, the Magi followed a star to find you. Help us follow your light this Advent season. You are the brightest star, the Light of the World! Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Advent Season — "We're waiting for Christmas, for Jesus!"
  2. Star Story — The Magi followed a star
  3. Star Facts:
  4. Stars are giant balls of hot gas that make light
  5. Our sun is a star!
  6. Stars light up the dark sky
  7. Jesus = Light — "Jesus is the light that lights up our lives!"
  8. Today's Challenge — "Engineer your own star!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Star Engineering (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Light Exploration (4 minutes)

  • Flashlight experiments:
  • Shine through different materials
  • Make star shapes with fingers (shadows)

  • "Stars give light in darkness"

  • "The Star of Bethlehem led the Wise Men to Jesus!"

Part 2: Engineer a Star (12 minutes)

Option A: Craft Stick Star

  • Arrange craft sticks in star shape

  • Glue together

  • Decorate with glitter, foil

  • Add string for hanging

Option B: Pipe Cleaner Star

  • Twist pipe cleaners into star shape

  • Create 3D structure

  • Add sparkly decorations

Option C: Woven Star

  • More complex pattern

  • Yarn or ribbon woven through frame

  • Teacher assistance available

All Stars:

  • Make it SHINE! (reflective materials)

  • This represents Jesus, our Light!

Part 3: Light Test (3 minutes)

  • Shine flashlight on stars

  • Watch them sparkle!

  • "Our stars light up, just like Jesus lights up our lives!"

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw your star design
  2. Write: "Jesus is the light because..."
  3. Draw the Wise Men following the star

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Star Display — Show off star creations
  2. Be a Star — "How can YOU shine Jesus's light?"
  3. Closing Prayer — "Jesus, Light of the World, help us shine your love. Guide us like the star guided the Wise Men. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Built star structure

  • Connected star to Advent meaning

  • Understood Jesus as Light

  • Designed with intention

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Pre-made star frame to decorate

  • Simpler star design

  • Work with partner

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Create multiple star designs

  • Make 3D standing star

  • Write Advent reflection

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Look at the night sky together! Find stars. Talk about the Star of Bethlehem. Make stars to decorate your home for Advent. Light Advent candles and talk about Jesus as Light.

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Display stars in classroom or church

  • Connect to Advent wreath and candles

  • Consider "star of the day" recognitions

  • Coordinate with religion class Advent activities

Previous: Session 06 — Gratitude Gifts Next: Session 08 — Digital Art

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 8 of 17

Students explore digital art creation using tablets, discovering how technology can be used for creative expression and praise.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Use a digital drawing app to create art

  • Explore digital tools (brush, colors, stamps)

  • Create a meaningful digital artwork

  • Connect digital creativity to praising God

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📱 Tablets with drawing app (such as: Kids Doodle, Drawing Pad, Tayasui Sketches)

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 🖼️ Examples of digital art

  • 📋 App navigation guide

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: Blessed Fra Angelico — A friar who created beautiful art for God's glory. If he lived today, he might use digital tools!

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "Sing to the Lord a new song." — Psalm 96:1 (We can also CREATE new things for the Lord!)

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, you made us creative like you. Thank you for new ways to make art! Help us use technology to create beautiful things that honor you. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Digital Art — "Today we make art on tablets!"
  2. New Tools — "Artists today use computers and tablets"
  3. Same Creativity — "Digital or paper—art comes from your creative mind!"
  4. Blessed Fra Angelico — Made art to praise God
  5. Today's Goal — "Create digital art that shows something beautiful!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Digital Art Creation (20 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: App Exploration (5 minutes)

  • Open drawing app

  • Explore tools:

  • 🖌️ Brushes (different sizes)
  • 🎨 Colors (palette or picker)
  • ⭕ Shapes

  • ↩️ Undo button (fix mistakes!)

  • Free exploration time

Part 2: Guided Creation (7 minutes)

  • Follow-along activity:
  • Draw a background (choose a color)
  • Add a main subject (suggest: flower, animal, house, or scene from nature)
  • Add details (sun, clouds, ground)

  • Add your name signature!

  • Teacher demonstrates on display if available

Part 3: Free Creation (6 minutes)

  • Create your own artwork!

  • Theme suggestions:

  • Something you love about God's creation
  • Your family
  • A place that makes you happy
  • Something you're thankful for

Part 4: Gallery (2 minutes)

  • Show neighbors your artwork

  • Share one thing you like about your creation

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw (on paper!) what you created digitally
  2. Write: "I made... because..."
  3. Circle: Creating digital art was: Fun! 😊 Hard 😰 Cool! 🎉

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Art Celebration — "You're digital artists!"
  2. Praising God — "Our creativity is a gift from God—use it to bring joy!"
  3. Closing Prayer — "Thank you, God, for creativity and new tools. Help us make beautiful things that make the world better. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Successfully used digital drawing tools

  • Created original artwork

  • Explored multiple features

  • Connected art to meaningful themes

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Focus on 2-3 tools

  • Pre-started template to add to

  • Partner exploration

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Explore advanced features

  • Create multiple artworks

  • Use layers or effects

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Try digital art at home if you have a tablet or computer! Many free drawing websites exist. Compare digital art to paper art—what's different? What's the same? Create art together!

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Pre-install and test drawing apps

  • Free apps: Kids Doodle, Tayasui Sketches Jr, Drawing Pad

  • Have backup paper art activity ready

  • Consider saving/printing student work

Previous: Session 07 — Star Makers Next: Session 09 — Faith Scientists

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 9 of 17

Students celebrate Catholic Schools Week by learning about Catholic women in STEM who showed that faith and science go together beautifully.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Learn about Catholic women scientists

  • Understand that women have always contributed to science

  • See faith and science as partners

  • Celebrate their Catholic school

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📸 Pictures of Catholic women scientists

  • 📄 Simple biographies (age-appropriate)

  • 🎨 Art supplies for tribute project

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 🎓 "Future Scientist" badge template

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text:
Catholic Women in Science:

  • Hildegard of Bingen — Saint who studied plants and medicine

  • Maria Gaetana Agnesi — Catholic mathematician

  • Sister Miriam Michael Stimson — Nun who helped discover DNA structure!

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "She is clothed with strength and dignity; she can laugh at the days to come." — Proverbs 31:25

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, thank you for all the women who have used their gifts to understand your world. Thank you for our Catholic school where we learn about faith AND science. Help us follow their example. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (6 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Catholic Schools Week! — "We're celebrating!"
  2. Women in Science — "Did you know women have always been scientists?"
  3. Meet Our Heroes:
  4. St. Hildegard of Bingen — Studied plants, wrote about medicine, music, and science 900 years ago!
  5. Maria Gaetana Agnesi — Catholic mathematician who helped poor people
  6. Sister Miriam Michael Stimson — A nun who helped scientists understand DNA (what makes you, YOU!)
  7. Faith + Science — "They loved God AND loved learning!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Honoring Women Scientists (18 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Story Focus - St. Hildegard (5 minutes)

  • Tell simplified story:
  • Lived long ago in Germany
  • Was a nun (woman who dedicated her life to God)
  • Studied plants and their healing powers
  • Wrote books about nature, music, and medicine

  • Believed studying nature helped her understand God better!

  • Discussion: "How did she show faith AND science together?"

Part 2: Tribute Project (10 minutes)

Option A: Scientist Portrait

  • Draw one of the women scientists

  • Add facts around the portrait

  • Write: "She loved God and science!"

Option B: "I Can Be a Scientist" Poster

  • Draw yourself as a scientist

  • Add: "Girls can be scientists!"

  • Include something you want to study

Option C: Thank You Card for Teachers

  • Thank teachers at your Catholic school

  • "Thank you for teaching us about God and science!"

Part 3: Future Scientists (3 minutes)

  • "Future Scientist" badges for everyone

  • "You can be a scientist who loves God too!"

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw one woman scientist you learned about
  2. Write: "She showed me that..."
  3. Write: "I'm thankful for my Catholic school because..."

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Celebrate — "Women can do anything! You can be a scientist!"
  2. Catholic School Pride — What do you love about our school?
  3. Closing Prayer — "Thank you, God, for all the women who have shown us that faith and science go together. Bless our Catholic school. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Learned about at least one woman scientist

  • Connected faith and science

  • Created tribute project

  • Expressed school pride

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Focus on one scientist story

  • Pre-drawn figure to decorate

  • Work with partner

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Research additional women scientists

  • Write longer biography

  • Present to class

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Look up one Catholic woman scientist together! Talk about how they used their gifts for God. Ask: "What do you want to learn about?" Girls: "You can be anything—including a scientist!"

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Coordinate with school Catholic Schools Week events

  • Invite a woman scientist from parish to visit

  • Display student work prominently

  • Reinforce: STEM is for everyone!

Previous: Session 08 — Digital Art Next: Session 10 — Magnets & Motion

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 10 of 17

Students explore the invisible force of magnetism, discovering how magnets push, pull, and make things move.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Understand that magnets attract some materials

  • Explore magnetic push and pull forces

  • Test objects for magnetic properties

  • Connect invisible forces to God's design

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📦 Magnets (bar and disc magnets)

  • 📦 Test objects (paperclips, coins, plastic, wood, foil, fabric)

  • 📋 Predict & Test chart

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 🧭 Compass (optional demonstration)

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: St. Hildegard of Bingen — She studied the natural world, including stones and their properties. She'd be fascinated by magnets!

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "He stretches out the north over the void and hangs the earth on nothing." — Job 26:7

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, you made invisible forces like magnetism that hold our world together. Thank you for the amazing things we can't see but know are real. Help us discover more about your creation today. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Magic or Science? — Show magnets sticking together (looks like magic!)
  2. Invisible Forces — "Magnets have INVISIBLE pulling power!"
  3. Attract & Repel:
  4. Magnets ATTRACT (pull toward) some things
  5. Magnets can also REPEL (push away) other magnets
  6. God's Invisible Design — "Many things in God's world are invisible but real—like love, air, and magnetic force!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Magnet Exploration (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Attract or Not? (7 minutes)

  • Predict & Test activity

  • For each object:

  • PREDICT: Will the magnet attract it? (yes/no)
  • TEST: Try it!

  • RECORD: What happened?

  • Test: paperclips, coins, plastic, wood, foil, pencil, fabric

  • Discovery: "What kinds of things are magnets attracted to?" (Metal things, especially iron/steel)

Part 2: Push and Pull (6 minutes)

  • Use two magnets

  • Try to stick them together different ways

  • Sometimes they attract (pull together)

  • Sometimes they repel (push apart)

  • "Magnets have two poles—north and south!"

  • Demo: Make magnets "chase" each other

Part 3: Magnet Challenge (6 minutes)

  • Challenge: Use magnets to move paperclips WITHOUT touching them!

  • Try through paper, cardboard, or thin plastic

  • "Magnetic force goes through things!"

  • Creative exploration time

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw objects that were magnetic vs. not magnetic
  2. Write: "Magnets attract..."
  3. Write: "Something invisible but real is..."

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Magnet Discovery — "What did you learn about magnets?"
  2. Invisible Things — "What else is invisible but real?" (God's love, air, gravity)
  3. Closing Prayer — "Thank you, God, for invisible forces that make our world work. Thank you for your invisible love that's always with us. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Predicted and tested magnetic properties

  • Observed attract/repel behaviors

  • Made connection to invisible forces

  • Recorded discoveries

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Fewer test items

  • Focus on attract only

  • Partner work

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Explore magnetic field patterns (iron filings if available)

  • Test more materials

  • Research how magnets are used in everyday life

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Go on a magnet hunt at home (use a refrigerator magnet)! What sticks? What doesn't? Test different metals—are they all magnetic? Where are magnets used in your home? (Refrigerator, cabinet doors, speakers)

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Magnet kits available from CSCOE

  • Small magnets can be swallowed—supervise carefully

  • Iron filings are messy but show field lines beautifully

  • Connect to Earth's magnetic field and compasses

Previous: Session 09 — Faith Scientists Next: Session 11 — Lenten Love

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 11 of 17

Students design and create something to help others during Lent, connecting engineering skills to the three pillars: prayer, fasting, and almsgiving.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Understand Lenten practices

  • Design something to serve others

  • Create a meaningful service project

  • Connect engineering to loving others

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📦 Craft supplies

  • 💜 Purple paper and decorations

  • 📦 Recycled materials for building

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • ❤️ Heart shapes

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: St. Teresa of Calcutta (Mother Teresa) — She dedicated her life to serving the poorest of the poor with great love.

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "Whatever you did for one of the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did for me." — Matthew 25:40

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear Jesus, during Lent we prepare our hearts for Easter. Help us find ways to love others as you loved us. Bless our hands as they work for others today. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Lent Season — "We're preparing for Easter!"
  2. Three Lenten Practices:
  3. 🙏 Prayer — Talking with God more
  4. 🍞 Fasting — Giving something up
  5. 💝 Almsgiving — Giving to those in need
  6. Mother Teresa — Served with love, said: "Do small things with great love"
  7. Today's Mission — "Design something loving for others!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Love in Action Project (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Who Needs Love? (3 minutes)

  • Brainstorm people who could use kindness:
  • Elderly neighbors
  • Sick classmates
  • Lonely people
  • Hungry families

  • Tired parents

  • Choose who to serve

Part 2: Design & Create (14 minutes)

Option A: Comfort Cards

  • Cards for hospital or nursing home

  • Include cheerful drawings

  • Message: "You are loved!"

  • Add hearts and encouraging words

Option B: Prayer Chain

  • Paper chain for people to pray for

  • Each link = one person/intention

  • Class prayer chain to display

Option C: Kindness Jar

  • Decorate a jar

  • Fill with kindness ideas on paper strips:

  • "Give a hug"
  • "Help clean up"

  • "Share a toy"

  • Take home to use during Lent

Option D: Care Packages Design

  • Design what would go in a care package

  • Draw items that would help someone in need

  • Plan actual collection

Part 3: Dedication (2 minutes)

  • "Who will receive your act of love?"

  • "Why is this important?"

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw your service project
  2. Write: "I made this for... because..."
  3. Write: "One way I can show love this Lent is..."

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Share Projects — Show what you made
  2. Lenten Commitment — What will YOU do for love?
  3. Closing Prayer — "Jesus, help us be like Mother Teresa—doing small things with great love. Bless our Lenten journey. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Understood Lenten practices

  • Designed with others in mind

  • Created service project

  • Made Lenten commitment

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Choose one project focus

  • Partner work

  • Pre-cut materials

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Create multiple items

  • Plan a family service project

  • Write prayer intentions

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Plan a family Lent service project! Ideas: Donate to food shelf, visit someone lonely, do extra chores, give up something and give the money away. Create a Lenten calendar together.

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Coordinate with school Lenten service projects

  • Consider delivering cards to nursing home

  • Connect to Rice Bowl or other parish initiatives

  • Purple is the liturgical color of Lent

Previous: Session 10 — Magnets & Motion Next: Session 12 — Butterfly Wonder

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 12 of 17

Students explore the butterfly life cycle and metamorphosis, discovering God's design for transformation and new life.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Identify the four stages of butterfly metamorphosis

  • Understand transformation as part of God's design

  • Create a butterfly life cycle model

  • Connect metamorphosis to spiritual transformation

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📸 Pictures of butterfly life cycle stages

  • 📦 Life cycle model materials (pasta shapes work well)

  • 🎨 Paper plates, paper, crayons

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 🦋 Butterfly specimens or photos

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: St. Paul — He was completely transformed on the road to Damascus, like a caterpillar becoming a butterfly!

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, the new creation has come: The old has gone, the new is here!" — 2 Corinthians 5:17

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, you designed the amazing butterfly transformation. Thank you for making all things new! Help us be transformed by your love. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Transformation Wonder — "Does a caterpillar LOOK like a butterfly?"
  2. Complete Change — "The caterpillar becomes something TOTALLY different!"
  3. Four Stages:
  4. 🥚 Egg
  5. 🐛 Caterpillar (larva)
  6. 🛖 Chrysalis (pupa)
  7. 🦋 Butterfly (adult)
  8. St. Paul Connection — "He was changed completely too!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Life Cycle Exploration (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Learn the Stages (6 minutes)

  • Show pictures/video of each stage:
  • Egg — Tiny, laid on a leaf
  • Caterpillar — Hatches, eats LOTS, grows
  • Chrysalis — Hangs and transforms inside

  • Butterfly — Emerges with wings!

  • "The caterpillar doesn't just get wings—it completely changes!"

  • Time frame: 3-4 weeks for most butterflies

Part 2: Life Cycle Model (10 minutes)

  • Create paper plate life cycle:
  • Divide plate into 4 sections
  • Add each stage:
    • Draw or glue small shape for egg
    • Pasta spiral or drawing for caterpillar
    • Pasta shell or folded paper for chrysalis
    • Drawn or cut-out butterfly
  • Add arrows showing cycle direction
  • Label each stage

Part 3: Transformation Connection (3 minutes)

  • Discussion: "How can WE be transformed?"
  • Learning new things (growing smarter)
  • Becoming kinder

  • Growing closer to God

  • "God wants to transform us into something beautiful too!"

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw the butterfly life cycle
  2. Label: Egg, Caterpillar, Chrysalis, Butterfly
  3. Write: "God transforms..."

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Life Cycle Share — Show your models!
  2. Easter Preview — "Easter is about the greatest transformation—Jesus rising to new life!"
  3. Closing Prayer — "God, thank you for transformation. Change us to be more like Jesus. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Named four life cycle stages in order

  • Created life cycle model

  • Connected to transformation themes

  • Related to spiritual growth

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Focus on caterpillar → butterfly change

  • Pre-made model to assemble

  • Partner work

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Add details and facts to each stage

  • Compare to other animal life cycles

  • Write about transformation

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Look for butterflies and caterpillars outside! Read a book about butterflies. If possible, get a butterfly kit and raise real butterflies at home. Talk about how God transforms us.

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Consider raising butterflies in classroom (kits available)

  • Great timing before Easter (transformation theme)

  • Connect to resurrection discussion

  • See Kindergarten lesson for simpler version

Previous: Session 11 — Lenten Love Next: Session 13 — Easter Joy

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 13 of 17

Students celebrate Easter's message of resurrection and new life through a joyful creative project.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Connect Easter to resurrection and new life

  • Create an Easter-themed project

  • Express Easter joy through art/engineering

  • Understand that Jesus makes all things new

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 🎨 Art supplies (various colors, especially spring colors)

  • 📦 Craft materials

  • 🌷 Flower/spring materials

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 📸 Pictures of Easter symbols

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: The Risen Jesus — The greatest moment in history: Jesus rose from the dead on Easter Sunday!

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "He is not here; he has risen!" — Luke 24:6

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Alleluia! Alleluia! Jesus is risen! Dear God, thank you for the gift of Easter and new life. Fill our hearts with joy today and always. Alleluia! Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. ALLELUIA! — "We can say Alleluia again! JESUS IS RISEN!"
  2. Easter Meaning:
  3. Jesus died on Good Friday
  4. He rose to NEW LIFE on Easter Sunday
  5. He conquered death—we have hope forever!
  6. Signs of New Life:
  7. Empty tomb
  8. Spring flowers
  9. Baby animals
  10. Butterflies (transformation!)
  11. Today's Celebration — "Create something to celebrate Easter joy!"

docs.title: Main Activity: Easter Celebration (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Easter Symbols (3 minutes)

  • Review symbols and meanings:
  • 🪨 Empty tomb — He is risen!
  • 🌷 Flowers — New life
  • 🦋 Butterfly — Transformation
  • 🐣 Eggs — New beginnings
  • 🐑 Lamb — Jesus, Lamb of God
  • ☀️ Sunrise — Easter morning

Part 2: Create (14 minutes)

Option A: Easter Garden

  • Build a mini Easter garden scene

  • Include tomb (cup or small container)

  • Stone rolled away

  • Add flowers, grass, cross

  • "He is not here—He is risen!"

Option B: New Life Collage

  • Collage of spring/new life images

  • Include: flowers, butterflies, eggs, sun

  • Add: "Alleluia! He is Risen!"

Option C: Resurrection Cross

  • Create a cross

  • Decorate with flowers and color

  • Symbol of victory over death

  • Add bright, joyful decorations

Option D: Easter Card

  • Card to share Easter joy

  • Include Easter message

  • Send to someone who needs hope

Part 3: Joy Celebration (2 minutes)

  • Gallery walk to see creations

  • Say together: "ALLELUIA!"

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw your Easter creation
  2. Write: "Easter means..."
  3. Write: "I have hope because..."
  4. Draw: Empty tomb OR butterfly OR flower

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Easter Message — "What does Easter mean to you?"
  2. Living Hope — "Jesus makes all things new—including us!"
  3. Closing Prayer — "Alleluia! Jesus is risen! Thank you for hope, for new life, for Easter joy! Help us share your love with everyone. Alleluia! Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Connected Easter to resurrection

  • Created meaningful Easter project

  • Expressed joy and hope

  • Understood Easter symbols

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Choose from 2 options

  • Pre-made materials to assemble

  • Focus on one symbol

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Include multiple symbols

  • Write Easter story or poem

  • Create for someone specific

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Attend Easter Mass together! Look for Easter symbols at church. Create an Easter garden at home. Take an Easter nature walk and find signs of new life. Share Easter hope with neighbors!

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Display Easter creations prominently

  • Coordinate with school Easter celebrations

  • Consider Easter egg hunt connection

  • Send cards to nursing homes if created

Previous: Session 12 — Butterfly Wonder Next: Session 14 — Sphero Challenge

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 14 of 17

Students apply their Sphero skills to complete mission challenges, demonstrating growth in programming and problem-solving.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Program Sphero to complete specific challenges

  • Problem-solve when programs don't work

  • Collaborate with teammates on missions

  • Demonstrate growth in coding skills

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📦 Sphero robots (from CSCOE library)

  • 📱 Tablets with Sphero Edu app

  • 🚧 Course materials (cups, tape, markers)

  • 📋 Mission challenge cards

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: St. Thomas Aquinas — He loved using logic and reason to solve problems. He'd enjoy programming challenges!

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "I can do all this through him who gives me strength." — Philippians 4:13

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, thank you for minds that can solve problems. When things get hard, help us keep trying. Give us patience, creativity, and teamwork today. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Sphero Experts — "Remember when we first met Sphero? Now you're EXPERTS!"
  2. Challenge Day — "Today you'll complete MISSIONS!"
  3. Problem-Solving Reminder:
  4. If it doesn't work, try again!
  5. Ask: What can I change?
  6. Work with your team!
  7. Let's Go!

docs.title: Main Activity: Mission Challenges (20 minutes)
docs.text:
Setup: Create course with tape lines and obstacles

Part 1: Quick Review (2 minutes)

  • Connect to Sphero

  • Review controls

  • Practice one movement

Part 2: Mission Challenges (16 minutes)

Mission 1: Target Practice (3 min)

  • Roll Sphero to stop inside a target circle

  • Points for accuracy!

  • Three tries each

Mission 2: Maze Navigator (4 min)

  • Navigate through simple tape maze

  • No wall touching!

  • Teamwork encouraged

Mission 3: Color Show (3 min)

  • Program color sequence:
  • Red, then blue, then green

  • Make it match the pattern!

  • Add movements between colors

Mission 4: Obstacle Course (4 min)

  • Navigate around cups without knocking them over

  • Speed matters, but so does accuracy!

  • Team record attempts

Mission 5: Creative Challenge (2 min)

  • Free programming time

  • Make Sphero do something COOL!

  • Share with class

Part 3: Celebration (2 minutes)

  • Celebrate achievements!

  • What did you figure out?

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw your favorite mission
  2. Write: "The hardest part was..."
  3. Write: "I solved it by..."
  4. Rate yourself: Beginner 🌱 Good 🌿 Expert 🌳

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Growth Reflection — "How have you improved since first trying Sphero?"
  2. Perseverance — "What did you do when it didn't work?"
  3. Closing Prayer — "Thank you, God, for helping us grow and learn. Thank you for patience when things are hard. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Completed at least 2 missions

  • Demonstrated improved skills from Session 3

  • Problem-solved when stuck

  • Collaborated with teammates

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Simplified mission versions

  • Extra teacher guidance

  • Partner with experienced peer

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Advanced missions with multiple steps

  • Create missions for others

  • Use "Draw" or "Block" programming

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Tell your family about the Sphero challenges! What was hard? What did you figure out? Talk about times when things didn't work and you had to try again. Perseverance pays off!

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Reserve Sphero 2 weeks ahead

  • Charge fully before class

  • This session shows growth from Session 3

  • Have backup missions ready

Previous: Session 13 — Easter Joy Next: Session 15 — Simple Machines

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 15 of 17

Students explore simple machines that make work easier, discovering how levers and ramps help us lift and move things.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Identify simple machines (lever, ramp/inclined plane)

  • Understand that machines make work easier

  • Experiment with levers and ramps

  • Connect engineering to helping others

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📦 Lever materials (rulers, pencils as fulcrums, small weights)

  • 📦 Ramp materials (books, boards, toy cars)

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 📸 Pictures of simple machines in use

  • 📦 Small objects to lift/move

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: St. Joseph the Worker — As a carpenter, he used simple machines every day to build and create!

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "Whatever you do, work at it with all your heart." — Colossians 3:23

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, thank you for simple machines that help us do hard work. Like St. Joseph, help us use tools wisely to serve others. Bless our learning today. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Heavy Lifting — "Have you ever had to lift something heavy?"
  2. Machines Help — "Simple machines make work EASIER!"
  3. Today's Focus:
  4. Lever — Like a seesaw! Helps lift things
  5. Ramp/Inclined Plane — Like a slide! Helps move things up
  6. St. Joseph — Used these tools as a carpenter
  7. Let's Experiment!

docs.title: Main Activity: Simple Machine Exploration (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Lever Investigation (8 minutes)

  • Build a lever:
  • Ruler balanced on a pencil (fulcrum)
  • Put a small object on one end

  • Push down on the other end

  • Experiments:

  • Move the fulcrum—what changes?
  • Closer to object = easier to lift!

  • Where are the best spots?

  • Discussion: "Where do we see levers?" (seesaw, door handle, scissors)

Part 2: Ramp Investigation (8 minutes)

  • Build a ramp:
  • Board or books propped on a stack

  • Roll car or push object up

  • Experiments:

  • Steep ramp vs. gentle ramp—which is easier?
  • Test with different objects

  • Measure how far things roll

  • Discussion: "Where do we see ramps?" (wheelchair ramps, playground slides, loading docks)

Part 3: Design Challenge (3 minutes)

  • Quick challenge: Use a lever OR ramp to move a small toy

  • Show your solution!

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw a lever you made
  2. Draw a ramp you made
  3. Write: "Simple machines make work easier by..."
  4. Draw where you see simple machines in the world

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Machine Discovery — "What did you learn about simple machines?"
  2. Helping Others — "How do ramps help people?"
  3. Closing Prayer — "Thank you, God, for simple machines that help us work. Help us always use our knowledge to serve others. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Built and tested lever

  • Built and tested ramp

  • Understood machines make work easier

  • Identified real-world examples

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Pre-built lever and ramp to experiment with

  • Focus on one machine type

  • Partner exploration

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Experiment with multiple fulcrum positions

  • Measure and record data

  • Research other simple machines (wheel, pulley)

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Find simple machines at home! Doorknobs, scissors, wheelbarrows, ramps for strollers. Build ramps for toy cars—test steep vs. gentle. Try making a lever to lift a book!

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Simple Machines Kit available from CSCOE

  • Great connection to playground equipment

  • Wheelchair ramps connect to accessibility/dignity discussion

  • Can extend to pulleys and wheels in future lessons

Previous: Session 14 — Sphero Challenge Next: Session 16 — Earth Care

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 16 of 17

Students explore environmental stewardship, designing solutions to help take care of God's creation.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Understand our responsibility to care for creation

  • Identify ways to reduce, reuse, and recycle

  • Design an eco-friendly solution

  • Connect environmental care to Catholic teaching

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📦 Recycled materials for building

  • 📸 Pictures of environmental challenges and solutions

  • 🌍 Globe or Earth picture

  • 📓 Design Detective journals

  • 🌱 Seed or plant materials (optional)

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: St. Francis of Assisi — Patron saint of ecology! He called the earth our "Sister" and cared for all creation.

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "The Lord God took the man and put him in the Garden of Eden to work it and take care of it." — Genesis 2:15

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, you created our beautiful Earth and asked us to take care of it. Help us be good stewards of your creation. Show us how to protect our planet. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Our Home — Show globe: "This is our home—the only Earth we have!"
  2. God's Gift — "God made Earth for us AND asked us to take care of it"
  3. Three R's:
  4. Reduce — Use less stuff
  5. Reuse — Use things again
  6. Recycle — Turn old things into new things
  7. St. Francis — Loved all of creation!

docs.title: Main Activity: Eco-Engineering (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Earth Challenges (4 minutes)

  • Discussion: What problems does Earth face?
  • Too much trash
  • Plastic in oceans
  • Wasted water

  • Pollution

  • "What can we do to help?"

Part 2: Eco-Design Project (13 minutes)

Option A: Reuse Creation

  • Build something NEW from recycled materials

  • Examples: bird feeder, pencil holder, planter

  • "This used to be trash, now it's useful!"

Option B: Eco-Poster

  • Create poster about taking care of Earth

  • Include tips: Turn off lights, recycle, use less plastic

  • Add drawings and messages

Option C: "Save Water/Save Energy" Signs

  • Design signs for classroom/home

  • "Turn off the water!"

  • "Turn off the lights!"

  • Place around school

Option D: Garden Planning

  • Plan a pollinator garden

  • What plants help bees and butterflies?

  • Design the layout

Part 3: Commitment (2 minutes)

  • "What ONE thing will you do to help Earth?"

  • Share commitments

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Draw your eco-project
  2. Write: "I can help Earth by..."
  3. Draw one thing you'll do differently

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Earth Promise — "What's your promise to creation?"
  2. Pope Francis — "He wrote about caring for 'our common home'!"
  3. Closing Prayer — "God, help us take care of your beautiful creation. May we be good stewards of the Earth. Amen."

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
Observation Checklist:

  • Identified environmental challenges

  • Created eco-friendly project

  • Made personal commitment

  • Connected care to faith

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Focus on one R (Reuse project)

  • Partner work

  • Simplified poster template

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Research and present environmental fact

  • Create multiple projects

  • Design implementation plan

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text: Family Activity: Do an eco-audit at home! How can your family reduce, reuse, and recycle more? Start a compost bin, use reusable bags, turn off lights. Make a family Earth Care promise!

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Connect to Laudato Si' (Pope Francis's encyclical on care for creation)

  • Consider school-wide eco initiatives

  • Display projects and posters

  • Coordinate with Earth Day activities

Previous: Session 15 — Simple Machines Next: Session 17 — Year Celebration

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Grades: 1-2 | Duration: 30 minutes | Session: 17 of 17

Students celebrate their year of C-STREAM discovery, sharing accomplishments and looking forward to future learning adventures.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this session, students will:

  • Reflect on their year of learning

  • Share favorite projects and discoveries

  • Celebrate growth in C-STREAM skills

  • Express excitement for continued learning

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• 📓 Design Detective journals (from all year)

  • 📸 Photos from C-STREAM sessions

  • 🏆 Certificates (optional)

  • 🎨 Display materials for work

  • 🎈 Celebration decorations

docs.title: Saint Connection
docs.text: All the Saints We Met This Year — St. Francis, Mother Teresa, Blessed Carlo Acutis, St. Joseph, and more showed us how faith and learning go together!

docs.title: Scripture
docs.text: "I thank my God every time I remember you." — Philippians 1:3

docs.title: Opening Prayer
docs.text: Dear God, thank you for an amazing year of discovery and learning! Thank you for our teachers, classmates, and all the wonderful things we've explored. Bless us as we continue to grow. Amen.

docs.title: Opening Circle (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Celebration Time! — "We did it! A whole year of C-STREAM!"
  2. Memory Lane — Show photos from the year's sessions
  3. Counting Learning:
  4. 17 sessions of exploring
  5. Towers, robots, butterflies, magnets, and more!
  6. Saints We Met — Quick list of saints from the year

docs.title: Main Activity: Exhibition & Celebration (19 minutes)
docs.text:
Part 1: Journal Review (5 minutes)

  • Students look through their Design Detective journals

  • Mark favorite pages

  • Find: "My best work" and "My biggest challenge I overcame"

Part 2: Partner Share (5 minutes)

  • Share with a partner:
  • Favorite project from the year
  • Something difficult you figured out

  • What you want to learn next

  • Partners celebrate each other!

Part 3: Class Gallery (5 minutes)

  • Display journals and saved projects

  • Gallery walk to see everyone's work

  • Give compliments!

Part 4: Awards & Looking Forward (4 minutes)

  • Optional certificates:
  • "Design Detective Champion"
  • "Tech Wizard"
  • "Earth Care Hero"
  • "Creative Engineer"

  • "Faith & Science Explorer"

  • Next year preview: "Even more adventures await!"

docs.title: Design Detective Journal (4 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Final journal entry:
  2. My favorite C-STREAM memory
  3. Something I learned about God's world
  4. What I want to learn next year

docs.title: Closing Circle (2 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Gratitude Circle — Each person: "I'm thankful for..."
  2. Summer Challenge — "Keep being a Design Detective all summer!"
  3. Final Blessing & Prayer:

Dear God, Thank you for this year of wonder. Thank you for creative minds and helping hands. Thank you for showing us that faith and science are friends. Bless these Design Detectives as they grow. Keep their curiosity alive forever. In Jesus' name, Amen.

🎉 CELEBRATION! 🎉

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
End-of-Year Reflection:

  • Can identify favorite learning experiences

  • Shows growth in design thinking

  • Demonstrates curiosity and wonder

  • Connects learning to faith

docs.title: For Students Who Need Support
docs.text:
• Help identify journal highlights

  • Partner for sharing

  • Focus on verbal celebration

docs.title: For Advanced Students
docs.text:
• Present to class

  • Create "advice" for next year's students

  • Write reflection letter

docs.title: Wonder at Home 🏠
docs.text:
Summer C-STREAM Challenge:

  • 🔍 Be a Design Detective everywhere!

  • 🏗️ Build with anything you find

  • 🤖 Notice technology around you

  • 🌿 Care for creation

  • 🦋 Watch for nature's changes

  • ❤️ Help others with your skills

  • 🙏 Thank God for wonder!

docs.title: Teacher Notes
docs.text:
• Prepare certificates in advance

  • Invite families if possible

  • Take lots of photos!

  • Send journals home as keepsakes

  • Celebrate each child's unique growth
